King George VI.Action: Reflects on his appearance with a self-deprecating, gentle humor, saying 'You look like a Christmas tree.'
Shows meticulous attention to detail in his military dress and appearance, displaying discipline and respect for tradition.
Internally acknowledges his own awkwardness and discomfort ('You look like a Christmas tree.') but maintains composure and a sense of humor.
Waves at his daughters and acknowledges their presence with a warm gesture.
Appears nervous and hesitant during the drive and broadcast preparations, showing vulnerability.
Nervously lights a cigarette before a public event; shows signs of anxiety but attempts to compose himself.
Acknowledges the advice of Elizabeth to 'buck up' and tries to face the challenge, indicating some level of resolve.
Allows anxiety and nervousness to manifest visibly despite the presence of others and the gravity of the occasion.
Bertie and Elizabeth take their places among dignitaries and brace for the public broadcast, showing readiness despite evident fear.
Shows visible terror when confronted with intimidating broadcast equipment in front of millions, indicating lack of confidence.
Shows visible signs of nervousness and lack of confidence during his speech attempt, demonstrating vulnerability.
Does not assert himself or push back against dismissive comments, reflecting humility but also passivity.
King George V dismisses Bertie’s difficulty by saying 'Just needs more practice,' showing limited empathy from the preceding generation rather than warmth from Bertie himself.
Has given up hope after seeing many specialists for his speech problem.
His wife Elizabeth notes that he has seen many specialists, but they were all useless and he has given up hope.
Despite difficulties, he has tried multiple avenues (specialists) to address his speech issues, showing persistence.
Has not taken direct action to seek treatment for his speech difficulties and is implied to have given up hope.
Needs to rely on others like Elizabeth and Lionel to manage and initiate his therapy process rather than acting himself.
His public role requires difficult skills such as public speaking, which he finds tormenting but feels obligated to perform.
Drops to his knees and waddles like a penguin to entertain his daughters, who giggle and listen raptly to his story despite his stutter.
Tells a simple, silly story to his daughters and gently puts them to bed.
Successfully tells a simple story to his children despite slight stammering, maintaining their attention and winning their affection.
Momentarily loses confidence and stutters when called upon to perform, revealing a vulnerability in public speaking.
Engages warmly and playfully with his children, showing emotional intelligence and presence.
Uncertain and hesitant in conversation with Elizabeth about David and the seriousness of a relationship, indicating difficulty addressing sensitive personal matters.
Prepares to give a speech despite discomfort with the microphone and setting, showing willingness to face a difficult task.
Shows visible discomfort and hesitation toward public speaking equipment, indicating insecurity in a critical skill.
Speaks frankly to Bertie about the challenges of kingship and family issues, showing insight and a willingness to engage sincerely.
Relays a story about confronting the Prince of Wales with distrust over his dishonesty, showing firmness but also a protective concern for family and duty.
Shows presence of mind to call the family a 'firm' and speaks candidly about serious issues affecting the monarchy.
Fails to project confidence when speaking into the microphone, exhibiting fear and anxiety.
Uses humor and pragmatism to address the difficult realities of royal duties and family crises.
Appears overwhelmed and uncertain in the face of new technological and public communication demands.
Relies on others to prepare and write his speeches, showing dependence rather than independent skill.
Is coached on technical aspects of using a microphone and delivering a speech, indicating lack of prior competence but willingness to learn.
Beckons Bertie and Elizabeth to join the balcony crowd despite the overwhelming noise, showing encouragement and inclusion.
Makes a blunt, somewhat disparaging comment about David bedding his 'American whore' in front of others.
Advises Elizabeth that she will need to participate more in public appearances, indicating an expectation but also a supportive gesture.
Steps out onto the balcony to greet the crowd despite the overwhelming noise and pressure.
Impatiently beckons for Bertie (himself) to join the balcony group, showing awareness of his own role and presence.
Encourages Elizabeth to accept the public role and implies the necessity of continued public appearances, showing acceptance of royal responsibilities.
Encounters difficulty speaking at the noisy factory, his stammer disrupts his ability to communicate effectively.
Continues attempting to speak in a challenging environment despite stammer and distractions, showing persistence.
Fails to anticipate the overwhelming noise and incoherent conditions at the factory speech venue, resulting in ineffective communication.
Expresses insecurity about public perception ('useless one who can't speak')
Smiles despite mood during Elizabeth's remarks
Reluctant to see the physician, showing hesitation
Attempts to attend speech therapy despite discomfort and anxiety.
Struggles visibly with stutter even in a supportive environment.
Admits to reluctance and discomfort in starting conversations, showing vulnerability and self-awareness.
Maintains formal distance with Lionel, insisting on titles despite Lionel's informal attempts.
Eventually allows Lionel to address him informally as 'Bertie,' showing trust and easing formality.
Expresses frustration and anger openly when challenged about his stutter and therapy, exploding in temper.
Attempts to assert a sense of equality and confidence towards Lionel by lighting a cigarette despite being told not to, showing some defiance.
Refuses to engage in personal self-reflection or introspection when asked about his earliest memory, shutting down dialogue.
Maintains awareness of his faults and acknowledges them with some self-deprecation.
Attempts to read aloud despite knowing his stutter will impair him, shows willingness to engage with his speech challenges.
Refuses to carry money citing royal status, showing a disconnected or rigid adherence to protocol in a casual situation.
Expresses bitterness openly about his stammer during reading, indicating emotional struggle but also honest self-awareness.
Admits to sounding terrible in the speech exercise
Engages in lighthearted banter with Lionel Logue about the wager
Shows frustration with the speech exercise but continues participation
Abruptly ends interaction with Lionel Logue by saying 'I'm finished with Doctor Logue'
Persists in practicing speech despite frustration and claims he was terrible, showing willingness to improve.
Dismisses the demonstration of the speech technique as 'rubbish' without fully accepting its value.
Elizabeth stops him from throwing away the record to avoid making a scene.
In fury rolls down the window and about to throw away the record.
Puts a comforting hand on his brother David's shoulder when he is sobbing.
Does not pursue or insist after David pulls away from his comforting gesture.
Puts a comforting hand on his brother David's shoulder, showing emotional support and empathy.
Approaches sensitive personal and family matters with discretion and restraint.
Fails to exert authority when David swears and shows disrespect toward an important guest (the Archbishop).
Acts as secretary helping compose the news release under pressure, showing involvement and responsibility.
No direct speaking or taking charge shown in this excerpt; appears passive during critical moment.
Expresses grief and despair openly to Elizabeth about recent events.
Shows anger and frustration toward Logue but restrains from physical destruction to avoid mess.
Listens to a flawless and flowing recording of his voice, showing progress in overcoming stutter.
Shows emotional reaction (tears with his wife) to the recording, indicating vulnerability but also resolve.
Despite hesitation, persists in seeking help from Logue, showing vulnerability and need for support.
Respectfully acknowledges Lionel's refusal and engages politely in the conversation.
Does not force entry or show aggression when initially refused.

Does not give up when initially denied entry, demonstrating persistence.
Appears unsure about social protocol, addressing Lionel informally and not prepared for resistance.
Asks to discuss personal matters privately, showing respect and consideration.

Apologizes sincerely for breaking Lionel's model airplane and offers to replace it.
Acknowledges his father's last words praising his courage, showing sensitivity and a desire to connect.

Refuses to sing when encouraged, possibly indicating social discomfort or reserve.

Attempts to engage in conversation and show empathy despite personal difficulty and silence about his brother's issues.

Shows self-awareness about his limitations by admitting inability to speak openly about his brother.
Changes subject awkwardly, revealing nervousness and discomfort.

Shows hesitation or self-consciousness about public behavior (waltzing or singing on State occasions), indicating vulnerability and sincerity.
Displays friendly and polite behavior by accepting offer of tea and engaging in casual conversation.

Surreptitiously wipes the rim of the mug before drinking, showing discomfort but discretion.
Responds to a rude question about Princess Elizabeth with visible anger but quickly composes himself and answers honestly.
Shares personal and somewhat embarrassing family history openly, revealing trust and honesty.
Flared in anger at a question about his personal life, showing some intolerance momentarily.
Surreptitiously wipes the rim of a chipped, possibly unclean mug with his handkerchief rather than openly rejecting it.
Manages to quickly regain control after flaring up at an inappropriate question, maintaining composure.
Engages in lighthearted conversation despite personal discomfort about becoming king and giving speeches.
Admits to having a temper and shows frustration during the therapy session, revealing vulnerability and openness.
Expresses judgmental attitude toward his brother's choice of woman, calling her 'wrong sort' mainly because she is American.
Engages with Lionel in a candid manner, sharing personal and painful childhood experiences.
Answers questions about his past with specific details, showing self-awareness about his childhood and medical history.
Expresses frustration and impatience openly during speech therapy session, showing difficulty managing emotions in a professional setting.
Maintains stubborn silence when confronted with personal emotional questions, indicating reluctance to engage vulnerably but also self-control.
Accepts therapy despite anxiety and doubt, pays Lionel promptly, shows vulnerability by admitting fear and anxiety about therapy and public scrutiny.
Expresses concern for the happiness of David but also adherence to family, Church, and nation expectations.
Admits to Lionel that he is the first ordinary Englishman he has really talked to, reflecting on how little he knows about common people's lives.
Remains silent and does not respond when asked about coming after the funeral, showing possible hesitation or reservation.
Engages in a reflective conversation with Lionel about understanding ordinary people's lives, showing self-awareness and thoughtfulness.

Stands very serious and composed during the declaration and military parade honoring his late father.

Appears frail and pale during the funeral cortege, hinting at vulnerability and pressure.
Appears frail and pale during the funeral cortege, suggesting nervousness and lack of confidence.

Admits to having a dreadful impediment in speech and is open about taking lessons to overcome it.
Shows visible anxiety and distress when asked unexpectedly to read Coronation Plans, indicating vulnerability.
Does not retaliate or respond confrontationally to David's teasing and pressure.

Kicks a soccer ball back to local lads, engaging casually and kindly despite his status.
Returns to Logue’s home nervously and humbly, showing trust and willingness to seek help.
Attempts to avoid attention by disembarking far from destination and covering his face.

Disguises his destination and approaches Logue's house nervously, indicating self-awareness and carefulness but also insecurity.
Integrates with local lads by engaging and kicking the ball, showing social adaptability and a degree of confidence.

Appears emotionally shattered and lost when recalling his inability to speak, revealing vulnerability and lack of confidence.
Apologizes to Mrs. Logue for the disturbance caused by swearing.
Expresses anger openly and uses strong language to vent frustration.
Rejects Lionel Logue's supportive gesture, showing distrust and defensiveness.
Acknowledges his duty to serve and expresses willingness to do anything to keep his brother on the throne.
Refers to his wife as a 'dear sweet deluded woman' who believes in him, showing affection despite frustration.
Expresses self-doubt about his ability to fulfill his role and doubts others' belief in him.
Acknowledges his duty to serve and the importance of purpose instilled from childhood.
Expresses doubt about his own ability and questions his motivation for seeking help.
Shows willingness to do anything within his power to keep his brother on the throne, even if it means debasing himself.
Concedes that he can 'bugger things up' and is not overconfident or blindly assertive.
Demonstrates realistic awareness of political obstacles regarding Mrs. Simpson's divorce and the coronation timeline.
Rejects Lionel Logue's encouragement, accuses him of trying to make him commit treason, reacts with anger and defensiveness.
Rejects Lionel Logue's encouragement and coaching, refuses to take advice, reacts defensively and accuses Lionel of trying to make him commit treason.
Asserts his royal lineage and sense of duty, despite personal doubts.
Expresses intention to try to be pleasant at the party despite family tensions.
Allows Elizabeth to bypass proper royal greeting protocol by not personally greeting her, which could be seen as a lapse in asserting his authority or presence as King.
By not actively managing court etiquette in this situation, his presence and command appear diminished, indicating a lack of confidence or assertiveness.
Tries to catch up to David and initiates a concerned conversation about the state of the monarchy and his brother's actions.
Maintains a serious tone when addressing David's inappropriate humor and is firm in trying to control the situation.
Allows David to back down after silent confrontation, avoiding escalation.
Expresses concern about the potential disaster caused by David's plans with Wallis, showing responsibility.
Does not intervene beyond verbal confrontation; refrains from harsher actions or public denunciation of David.

Insists on the importance of national unity and identity, emphasizing the family’s English legacy ('Because we took an English name! Windsor. Because we are England. We are the heart and soul of this nation. That must never change.')

Firmly reminds David of his constitutional role and the limits of his power, emphasizing his responsibility as a King and respect for government decisions ('David, your role is to consult and to be advised.', 'If you refuse to listen to our Government, they have no choice but to resign.')
Rejects David’s rebellious stance and dismissal of authority with no evident tolerance or effort to understand his viewpoint
Begging David not to do this to his wife, daughters, and himself.
Insisting that they are not ordinary men, emphasizing duty over personal feelings.
Acknowledges his speech impediment and strives to improve, showing noticeable improvement in his public speeches.
Expresses self-doubt and a feeling of inadequacy about being King, reflecting inner uncertainty about his role.
Asks for empathy and understanding from others regarding his struggles, demonstrating emotional honesty but possibly lacking outward confidence.
Silent presence in discussion where others are blunt and harsh; does not assert dominance or harsh judgment in a tense political debate.

Expresses disbelief and concern about his brother's actions and intentions.

Shows apprehension about political upheaval and war, expressing a desire to avoid conflict.

Rejects Winston Churchill's new speech, saying 'I don't want to hear it! Ever!'
Acknowledges the heavy burden of responsibility and his need for support to discharge his duties as King.

Children curtsy formally and do not respond to his gesture of solace; he is visibly devastated by this lack of warmth.
Expresses emotional vulnerability by fearing loss of his wife Elizabeth and openly discussing it with her.
Responds to Elizabeth's reassurance and encouragement, showing willingness to accept his new responsibilities with determination.
Stops outside the consultation room and listens respectfully to Anna reading poetry.
Tells Anna that he would be honored if she tells Harold what he said.
Admits he was frightened and took refuge in his royal status, acknowledges that what he said was unforgivable.
Expresses humility openly, admits to having been frightened and taking refuge in being 'Royal', and shows willingness to acknowledge mistakes.
Seeks help actively despite the dignity concerns, indicating pragmatic self-awareness.
Blurts out a key insight: 'What's the one essential thing a King must do? He must believe he is King...', demonstrating emerging self-reflection and grasp of his role.

Begging Lionel to help him through his insecurity, offering to pay him more out of desperation.
Shows frustration and self-doubt ('I wouldn't know') but does not lash out at others.
Listens patiently to Churchill and Lang's discussion without openly dismissing or mocking them.
Lets Lang's joke about his brother pass without offense, showing tolerance.
Engages thoughtfully about his brother's new title, showing sincerity and consideration.
Figures out that making the Duke of Windsor a Royal Duke and titling him His Royal Highness prevents him from standing or voting in Parliament, effectively managing a sensitive political issue.
Shows modesty and self-awareness by admitting certain sounds are hardest for him during speech exercises.
Engages politely and respectfully in a conversation with Elizabeth and Myrtle despite underlying tensions.
Demonstrates avoidance or reluctance to confront uncomfortable social situations by remaining 'in hiding' and not going out to speak with others.
Reluctantly accepts to enter the room first despite obvious nervousness, showing deference to others’ wishes.

Does not engage in family tension or conflict during the meal; remains quiet.

Jokes self-deprecatingly about his public speaking ('assault upon the ears of the listeners').

Explodes emotionally demanding to be heard, showing passion but also a loss of composure.

Follows Lionel Logue into the Abbey to rehearse coronation proceedings, engaging actively in preparation work.

Thanks Logue sincerely for asking difficult questions and offers recompense.
Pins a personally designed medal on Logue as a token of appreciation and calls him 'old friend'.
Shows visible signs of anxiety and vulnerability before the speech.
Maintains calm and steadies himself to deliver a difficult wartime speech to his people, conveying sincere care and connection.
Shows vulnerability in his initial struggle but overcomes it to communicate trust and confidence to his audience.
Despite initial severe stammering symptoms, he applies practiced techniques to steady his hands and relax his throat, enabling him to deliver a composed, clear radio address without hesitation.
Shows internal struggle and anxiety manifesting physically before the speech, such as shaking hands and constricted throat, indicating initial lack of confidence.
Successfully delivers a motivational and unifying speech to a wide audience across the Commonwealth and the world, demonstrating awareness of his role and the gravity of the moment.
Delivers a heartfelt radio address acknowledging the fears and challenges faced by his people and calls for unity and calm in difficult times.
Takes Lionel Logue by the shoulders and gives him a hug, breaking formal barriers.

King George V.Action: Expresses deep gratitude and love to his people during the Silver Jubilee speech, dedicates himself anew to their service.
Acknowledges the role of the Archbishop and the News Reader in helping him prepare his speech with modesty and friendliness.
Whispers instructions privately to Wigram about the Instruments of Succession, showing trust in his aide and concern for smooth transition.
Glares at David when he barely makes his mark on the documents.
Waves others out of room but keeps Wigram close, showing selective engagement but private and reserved behavior.

Bertie.Action: Reminds Queen Mary she is not dying, shows blunt but possibly caring honesty.
